perturbation.original_text: Any and all disputes, controversies and claims arising out of or relating to this Agreement or concerning the respective rights or obligations of the parties hereto shall be settled and determined by arbitration in the defending parties home forum before one (1) arbitrator pursuant to the Commercial Rules then in effect of the American Arbitration Association. Each party shall have no longer than three (3) days to present its position. Judgment upon the award rendered may be entered in any court having jurisdiction or application may be made to such court for a judicial acceptance of the award and an order of enforcement. The parties agree that the arbitrators shall have the power to award damages, injunctive relief and reasonable attorneys' fees and expenses to any party in such arbitration.
perturbation.changed_text: Any and all disputes, controversies and claims arising out of or relating to this Agreement or concerning the respective rights or obligations of the parties hereto shall be settled and determined by arbitration in the defending parties home forum before one (1) arbitrator. Judgment upon the award rendered may be entered in any court having jurisdiction or application may be made to such court for a judicial acceptance of the award and an order of enforcement.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the reference to the Commercial Rules of the American Arbitration Association and the specific clause regarding the arbitrator's power to award damages, injunctive relief, and attorney's fees, this modification creates a potentially non-compliant arbitration clause. Many states require that arbitration agreements clearly outline the scope of the arbitrator's authority, particularly concerning remedies. Deleting these provisions introduces ambiguity and could render the clause unenforceable, thus violating consumer protection laws in some jurisdictions. Furthermore, limiting each party to only three days to present its position is an unreasonably short timeframe that may violate due process requirements for fair arbitration, potentially contradicting state laws mandating fair business practices.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State laws governing arbitration agreements and consumer protection laws regarding fair business practices. Specifically, laws relating to the enforceability of arbitration clauses and the scope of arbitrator authority.

perturbation.original_text: Drkoop.com warrants to Sponsor that it will make reasonable effort to perform under this agreement in a competent manner. * * *
perturbation.changed_text: Drkoop.com makes no warranties to Sponsor regarding performance under this agreement. * * *
perturbation.explanation: By removing the warranty of 'reasonable effort to perform in a competent manner', the contract eliminates a basic guarantee of service quality. This omission introduces legal risk because, under common law and the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), there's an implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing in contracts. Eliminating the explicit warranty weakens the Sponsor's legal recourse if drkoop.com's performance is substandard, potentially violating implied contract law principles. Additionally, removing the warranty can be seen as an unconscionable act, especially if the Sponsor has little bargaining power, opening the door to legal challenges under consumer protection laws or similar regulations in various states.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing; Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) provisions on contract performance; State consumer protection laws regarding unconscionable contracts.

perturbation.original_text: Sponsor shall use its best efforts to keep User Data confidential and shall only use such data in an ethical manner. Sponsor may use User Data for its owns purposes, but User Data may not be disclosed, sold, assigned, leased or otherwise disposed of to third parties by Sponsor.
perturbation.changed_text: Sponsor may use User Data for its own purposes.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the obligations to 'use its best efforts to keep User Data confidential' and the prohibition against disclosing, selling, assigning, leasing, or otherwise disposing of User Data to third parties, this modification creates a significant privacy risk for users. This contradicts various state and federal laws regarding data privacy and security, such as the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) and the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) if health information is involved. The omission eliminates essential protections for user data, making the agreement non-compliant with privacy regulations and potentially exposing drkoop.com and Vitamin Shoppe to legal liabilities and penalties.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA); Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) if applicable; State data breach notification laws; Federal Trade Commission (FTC) Act Section 5 regarding unfair or deceptive trade practices related to data privacy.
